text: well on balance I think trade has been
beneficial to the United States yes uh I
was Majority Leader when we passed naft
I supported it uh I supported the
creation of the World Trade
Organization one of the areas I tend to
disagree with uh the uh two democratic
presid enal candidates uh but it's
understandable their position is is that
we ought to well they don't quite say we
ought to repeal them but they say we
have to renegotiate them uh and and if
you can renegotiate them fine but uh uh
you could to deal with the other
signatories to these treaties I think uh
I think the debate has been incomplete
with respect to trade uh it is true that
it does produce adverse effects of that
that can be no doubt it's like most
public policy
issues uh uh but it also produces very
beneficial effects which we ought to
include in the debate and in the
discussion I do believe strongly that we
can do a much better job in negotiating
trade agreements to deal with the very
troubling issues of uh uh health health
care Environmental Protection very low
wages in other societies that is work of
protection issues to uh neutralize some
of the difficulties that we have we have
not done a good job at that uh but uh
the answer is not to build walls of
protection the answer is to keep what's
working and trade generally is
beneficial uh and try to deal with the
adverse effects the reality is of course
that uh there is dislocation there's
much dislocation
uh but uh it's very hard to identify a
specific and direct cause and effect
relationship with respect to all
dislocation because much of it comes
from a dynamic free market economy and
you want
Innovation uh you know there used to be
a lot of people in this country employed
in the manufacturer stage coaches they
aren't any anymore they they all when
the motor vehicle was invented uh Stage
Coach production ended and people made
motor vehicles and that meant
dislocation for those who've been
engaged in stage coach production and
other related Industries but the country
is clearly better off that didn't have
anything to do with any trade agreement
that was the the result of innovation in
a dynamic free market economy which we
have which we want and which we should
encourage I emphasize I I'm not for
just trading for the sake of trading you
have to have an objective and we can do
a much better job at mitigating the
admittedly harsh effects on individuals
when I was a boy uh my mother as I
mentioned earlier was a textile mill
worker and she worked at a number of
Mills I think at one time there were
about 20 textile mills of one kind or
another within an hour's Drive of our
home I don't think there's a single one
now they just gone first to the South
and then uh to Asia and now there are
real effects to that Maine on in another
example was once the largest
manufacturer of all of the states in
production of Footwear
shoes that's pretty much gone now so so
so you you get benefits you get
disadvantages but you you can't build
walls well of course uh the WTO is a a
legal regime which is intended to
encourage trade
while creating a forum to deal with
unfair practices in trade uh it's highly
imperfect all human institutions are
from the dawn of
civilization every society has sought to
manipulate trade in its favor and of
course for much of what I would call
Modern History uh the Tariff or tax on
Imports was the mechanism by which uh
that was accomplished so-called
protecting domestic Industries but uh
most economic historians uh and others
believe that the protectionist response
to the slowdowns of the 1920s and
1930s uh contributed to the depression
which in turn contributed to the second
world war and uh I I think you have to
be very careful to guard against that
now it's a very different world now
there are 6 A5 billion people on Earth
the population is now expected to grow
although population projections are
notoriously unreliable because changes
can produce uh uh changes in human
behavior can produce shop changes in
population projections but I think the
best estimates now will will Peak
between 8 billion and 9 billion that's
an enormous number of people with a huge
demand for land for water for food for
the uh
education uh to to think that you can
deal with those issues and 90% of that
population growth will occur in poorer
areas think you can deal with that
by creating protectionist walls I think
is a profound error
